title: Erdős Problem #825: Abundancy Bound for Weird Numbers
description: Is there an absolute constant C > 0 such that every n with σ(n) > Cn is the distinct sum of proper divisors of n? Equivalently, do weird numbers have bounded abundancy?

overview.historicalContext: Benkoski and Erdős studied weird numbers—abundant numbers that are not semiperfect. The smallest weird number is 70. Erdős asked whether sufficiently high abundancy σ(n)/n forces semiperfectness, offering a $25 prize. The problem remains open. No odd weird number is known (Erdős Problem #470).
overview.problemStatement: Is there an absolute constant C > 0 such that every n with σ(n) > Cn is the distinct sum of proper divisors of n?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines divisor sums, proper divisors, semiperfectness, and weird numbers. It axiomatises the known lower bound C > 2 (from the counterexample n = 70) and the connection to odd weird numbers. The main conjecture and the strengthened C = 3 version are stated.
keyInsights: A weird number is abundant but not semiperfect; 70 is the smallest
The constant C must exceed 2, as σ(70) > 2·70 but 70 is weird
If no odd weird numbers exist, all weird numbers have abundancy < 4

sections.summary: Semiperfectness (distinct sum of proper divisors equals n) and weirdness (abundant but not semiperfect).

sections.title: Known Examples
sections.summary: 70 is the smallest weird number with σ(70) = 144.

sections.title: Lower Bound on C
sections.summary: Any valid constant C must satisfy C > 2, demonstrated by n = 70.

sections.title: Odd Weird Numbers
sections.summary: No odd weird number is known up to 10²¹. If none exist, weird numbers have abundancy < 4.

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Erdős Problem 825: weird numbers have bounded abundancy, conjecturally C = 3.

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures Erdős Problem 825, asking whether weird numbers have bounded abundancy index. The known lower bound C > 2 and the conjectured C = 3 are both stated.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would show that sufficiently abundant numbers are always semiperfect, limiting the 'density' of weirdness. This connects to the open question on odd weird numbers (Problem #470).
openQuestions: Does the constant C exist at all?
